item.title: â€˜Come on Joe you know it makes senseâ€™: Hart urged to leave Burnley for rivals Preston by fan Andrew Flintoff amid Deepdale link
item.description: Former England number one Joe Hart is not having the best of times at Burnley, having recently been axed for Tom Heaton, and with Nick Pope returning from injury.
item.content:encoded:
Former England number one Joe Hart is not having the best of times at Burnley, having recently been axed for Tom Heaton.

However, he does have some options, and England cricket legend Andrew Flintoff has urged Hart to find a start elsewhere.

Namely, Burnley's local rivals Preston North End, who are currently playing in the Championship.


'It makes sense to move to a bigger club!!' Joked Preston fan Flintoff on Twitter. 'Come on Joe you know it makes sense.'

According to The Sun, Preston are looking for a new goalkeeper and have asked their neighbours if they can have the out of favour Hart, who only joined Burnley at the start of this season.

With Tom Heaton now first choice, and with Nick Pope returning from injury, Joe Hart may find himself less and less of use to the Premier League team.

He would be getting regular football in the Championship with Preston, though. They have just let Chris Maxwell go to Charlton on loan.

Preston are also reportedly keeping an eye on Middlesbrough's Connor Ripley, who's currently at loan at Accrington.

Tom Heaton was given his first Premier League start in 15 months against West Ham, and Sean Dyche was rewarded with a clean sheet in Burnley's 2-0 win.

Prior to that, Burnley had a string of mostly bad results, with losses to Newcastle, Crystal Palace, Liverpool, Tottenham, Arsenal, and Everton.

Nick Pope started between the sticks against Barnsley in the FA Cup, earning them another clean sheet.

Burnley are currently 16th in the Premier League, two points above the relegation zone.

Preston are also struggling in the Championship, sitting in 17th.

item.content:encoded:
Two years may have passed but Ross McCormack is never likely to forget. As the striker looks to restate his worth in a loan spell at Motherwell, he has accused Steve Bruce of 'hanging him out to dry' with the personal and very public castigation that signalled a sharp career decline.

In January 2017, Bruce claimed McCormack had excused himself from training at Aston Villa because the electric gates at his home couldn't open. He went further by stating he would not consider the Scotland international for selection until his attitude improved.

There would be no reconciliation. McCormack insists their relationship had broken down before that extraordinary press conference, but Bruce's words served to alter the wider perception of his professionalism.

That accusation is one he fiercely rejects, pointing to his success as a captain with both Leeds United and Fulham.

It was from the latter that McCormack made a Â£12million move to Villa in the summer of 2016. But the sacking of Roberto di Matteo and the appointment of Bruce marked a seismic shift in his hopes for success in the Midlands.


McCormack was loaned out to Nottingham Forest before similar spells with Melbourne City and Central Coast Mariners in Australia. It felt like an extraordinary position for a player who had previously been one of the most consistent, and valuable, scorers in the English Championship.

Speaking at Motherwell's training camp in Tenerife, the 32-year-old traces it all back to that clash with Bruce.

'I don't think it was a personality thing,' he reflected. 'I think it was personal. A lot of things had been said. It didn't happen instantly. A lot of things I will keep to myself for now.

'Looking back, I actually started his first game in charge so it wasn't as if he has just come in and said, "I don't fancy Ross". I'm not sure if I started again after that.

'There was something massive that happened before (the comments about the electric gates). That's what disappointed me the most because, no two ways about it, he hung me out to dry with that.

'The gate problem was real. I never said I wasn't coming in. I just said I'm running a little bit late.

'The next thing, the headlines. I think it came because Villa were 2-0 up at home to Preston and conceded two late goals. Being clever, he probably tried to shift the blame on me. Which is fine but, in the process, as I said, something big happened before. Going down that route publicly was probably not helpful.'

Certainly, it created a toxic public impression of McCormack's reliability. Mud sticks. Especially in a business as tight-knit as football.

'What I say to people who don't know me and listen to people who say I'm a bad egg or whatever is that I was club captain at Fulham and club captain at Leeds,' countered McCormack.

'That was about four years in a row. Have you ever met a club captain who's a bad egg? Me neither.

'And the stats. The stats back it up. Until I went to Aston Villa I was scoring x amount. It just didn't happen there. That's it.

'I have seen it happen with loads of players. They get frozen out and leave.. It just feels there was a little more needle in mine.

'Did him going public make it hard for me to recover? Recover is a very good word. I just didn't think that was the right way to go.'

McCormack now looks on at Fulham spending big in the English Premier League.. With another 18 months left on his Villa contract, he admits some regret at quitting West London.

'Hindsight is a wonderful thing, but I was maybe too quick to leave Fulham,' he added. 'I'm not just saying that because they are in the Premier League now and I might have been there and I was club captain. It was maybe just a year too soon.'

He went from being a hot property in the English game to assisting goals for Usain Bolt when the Olympic sprint legend had an unsuccessful crack at becoming a professional footballer with Central Coast Mariners last year.

'The best thing about that was he was a humble guy,' smiled McCormack. 'He would come and have coffee with the lads like he was anyone, really.

'I have never seen anything like it. I have been with John Terry or Barry Ferguson in Glasgow and a lot of people recognise them. If this guy walks down the street, the full street chase after him. But he was such a nice guy and gelled well with the boys.

'I set him up for his first goal. He used his pace well! He was a good guy. He could have sat on the beach chilling but he had a go.'

He is now seeking to make a mark at Motherwell - with whom he had a successful stint between 2006 and 2008 - in a fourth loan spell away from Villa. Currently working to overcome a knee issue, he hopes to be fit and available for the Premiership meeting with Hibernian on January 23.

'I've got a lot to prove to myself because confidence has been on the floor in the last couple of years,' McCormack admitted.

'Coming here is a good chance for me. The kids will get to see me play. If I didn't come back to Scotland now, it would have been harder in the summer.. Before you know it, you are having to see out the rest of your career in Australia and the kids never see me play again. That was a major factor. My focus now is the next five months and Motherwell.'

item.title: 'Being a part of the history and doing something special here would be amazing': Jermain Defoe set sights on trophies at Rangers as he begins 18-month loan spell from Bournemouth
item.description: The 36-year-old striker revealed that the rich past and scale of the Ibrox club were key attractions in his decision to join, in addition to the chance to work for ex-England team-mate Steven Gerrard.
item.content:encoded:
Jermain Defoe is targeting a place in Rangers history as he begins his 18-month loan spell from Bournemouth.

The 36-year-old striker revealed that the rich past and scale of the Ibrox club were key attractions in his decision to join, in addition to the chance to work for ex-England team-mate Steven Gerrard.

Rangers haven't won a major trophy since 2011, but are level on points with Celtic at the top of the Premiership - having played a game more - and still have a Scottish Cup campaign to come.


Defoe admitted silverware was high in his thoughts for the remainder of this season and next as he seeks to make a mark north of the border.

'I wanted to come here for obvious reasons; I've always known it's a massive football club,' said Defoe, who underwent his first training session in Tenerife on Tuesday.

'The history of the club... as players those are the sorts of clubs you want to play for and do well at. You want to be part of the history if you can.

'It was an easy decision to be honest. If you love your football like me and you get an opportunity like this it's hard to turn it down.

'I've been in the Premier League for so long and it's always nice to have a different challenge.

'Sometimes you can - not get comfortable - but you are in your comfort zone there and sometimes it's nice to get away from that and just try and find that fire again, set targets and have a different challenge.

'Winning trophies was another draw, especially how well the lads have done since Stevie has been in.

'Being a part of the history and doing something special here, that would be amazing to be involved in.'

Defoe is one of two January signings made by Gerrard, with midfielder Steven Davis having returned to Rangers on a six-month loan from Southampton. A pre-contract deal for Glen Kamara could also be accelerated into a move this month, with Dundee trying to strike a sale agreement after recalling him from a Finland training camp.

'Steven Gerrard had a big influence because he's an ex-teammate and someone I've always admired and respected,' Defoe told Rangers TV.

'He's a young manager and his enthusiasm is amazing. He wants to do well and, like me, he wants to be part of the history of Rangers and create something special.

'But even before Steven I've known the size of this club and the support, they are special football fans.

'It might be a little bit strange having him as my manager. I had it a little bit with Eddie Howe because I was on at loan at Bournemouth when I was really young but only for a few months.

'With this, it will probably be a lot different. My time with England with Stevie was good and we now just have to get on with it, do the best we can and try and build something positive for the team.'

Defoe could link with Alfredo Morelos in a revamped Rangers attack. While the Colombian's part in incidents in the recent Old Firm game captured headlines, Gerrard insists the striker is often more sinned against than sinner when it comes to physical confrontations.

And the Rangers manager argues that attention is a mark of how he has become the Premiership's most feared striker.

'Everyone singles out Alfredo - he's a target for everyone,' said Gerrard. 'In the first half of the season he scored 20 goals. He's been the best striker in the league by a country mile so he should see his treatment as a compliment - I would if I was him.

'I can assure everyone that we are working with Alfredo and he's certainly doing his best to try and improve his discipline on the pitch.

'He is very young, he is a target. He gets kicked from pillar to post in the majority of games and teams set out to try and stop him and the only way they can stop him is to be physical with him.

'But we get on with it, he gets on with it. He handles it in the main very well. Of course he's made a couple of mistakes along the way but doesn't everyone at his age?'

item.content:encoded:
Chelsea have recalled Lewis Baker from his loan at Leeds United and are poised to let him join Reading.

The 23-year-old had struggled to make an impression at Elland Road making 14 appearances.

Reading have rejected an offer of Â£450,000 from Wigan to sign defender Tyler Blackett. The 24-year-old also has interest from Middlesbrough and Stoke City.


Chelsea, meanwhile, have also cut short midfielder Kasey Palmer's loan at Blackburn Rovers so that he can move to Bristol City on loan.

Palmer, 22, has only made ten starts at Blackburn this season and will become the third Chelsea player on loan at Ashton Gate, joining Tomas Kalas and Jay DaSilva.

item.title: Liverpool youngster Rafael Camacho set to return to Sporting Lisbon on loan despite making debut at Wolves
item.description: The 18-year-old deputised at right-back as he made his first-team bow during Liverpool's FA Cup third-round defeat by Wolves at Molineux on Monday night.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool youngster Rafael Camacho is heading back to Sporting Lisbon on loan.

The 18-year-old deputised at right-back as he made his first-team bow during Monday night's FA Cup third-round defeat by Wolves.

But Jurgen Klopp is to allow him to continue his development away from the Anfield spotlight and back in his native Portugal.


Camacho joined Liverpool from Manchester City's academy in 2016 after leaving Lisbon at the age of 13.

Last season he made the bench for the Merseyside derby at Goodison Park and has been earmarked as a future star.

Nominally a forward, Camacho's versatility has seen him cover a number of positions, with former Under 18 coach Steven Gerrard converting him into a right-back last season.

item.content:encoded:
Cardiff City's Â£10million move for Nice midfielder Adrien Tameze has collapsed.

Julien Fournier, Nice's general manager, confirmed the Premier League club pulled out of negotiations on Tuesday night, despite a fee having been agreed earlier at Â£8million plus Â£2m in add-ons.

Cardiff were excited at finally getting a quality player in to help their cause but negotiations broke down and Neil Warnock will now have to explore alternatives.


Tameze has made 50 appearances for Nice since making his move there in 2017 from Valenciennes

Meanwhile, Cardiff winger Anthony Pilkington is close to joining Wigan Athletic, pending a medical.

Pilkington, 30, is holding talks with Paul Cook's Championship side after accepting he has no long-term future in South Wales.

Cardiff missed out on signing Nathaniel Clyne last week when the right back opted to choose to go to Bournemouth on loan instead, prompting Warnock to label Liverpool 'a disgrace and a lack of class'.

item.title: Sporting Gijon 2-1 Valencia: English forward Nick Blackman scores the winner for the second tier side in the Spanish Cup
item.description: Sporting Gijon's English forward Nick Blackman came off the bench to score the winner as the Spanish second-tier side beat floundering Valencia 2-1 in the first leg of their Copa del Rey last 16 tie.
item.content:encoded:
Sporting Gijon's English forward Nick Blackman came off the bench to score the winner as the Spanish second-tier side beat floundering Valencia 2-1 in the first leg of their Copa del Rey last 16 tie on Tuesday.

Blackman, on loan from Derby County, had been on the pitch for under 60 seconds when he headed home from close range after Valencia had failed to properly clear a corner, giving Sporting a famous victory at their Molinon ground.

Sporting, the club where Valencia coach Marcelino began his playing career and spent two years as manager, took the lead in the 35th minute through left back Javi Noblejas.


The visitors levelled on the stroke of half-time with a long-range strike from Dani Parejo which bounced over the line after striking the crossbar, with the goal being awarded after the referee consulted the video technology (VAR).

Valencia, who are 12th in La Liga with coach Marcelino under increasing pressure, have the opportunity to turn the tie around in next Tuesday's second leg at their Mestalla stadium.

item.title: Chelsea boss Maurizio Sarri slams decision to award Tottenham's Harry Kane a penalty... as Mauricio Pochettino admits: 'I don't like VAR'
item.description: Maurizio Sarri slammed Harry Kane's controversial VAR goal on Tuesday night as Tottenham took a step closer to Wembley. Kane's first-half penalty gave Tottenham a narrow advantage over Chelsea.
item.content:encoded:
Maurizio Sarri slammed Harry Kane's controversial VAR goal on Tuesday night as Tottenham took a step closer to Wembley.

Kane's first-half penalty gave Tottenham a slender 1-0 advantage to take to Chelsea in two weeks' time.

But the goal was mired in uncertainty after referee Michael Oliver referred the incident - that saw Kane tripped in the area by Kepa Arrizabalaga - to VAR.


Initial TV replays appeared to show that Kane was onside as he raced onto Toby Alderweireld's pass.

But alternative camera angles seem to suggest the Tottenham striker was offside before the collision with Chelsea keeper Kepa.

Chelsea players were seen questioning the referee in the tunnel at half-time, clearly unhappy that the penalty was awarded.

And Sarri said: 'A few minutes ago I watched the video from our camera. It was offside. Our camera was in line with Harry Kane.

'Offside with his head, the knee. Offside. It was really important the linesman carried on running, he had a big impact on our defenders.

'I don't think English referees are able to use the system. If you are not sure with the system, you have to follow the ball and at the end of the action decide.

'But he stopped and didn't follow the ball - for our defenders it was offside.

'It's very strange in the Premier League there isn't VAR and in Carabao Cup there is the system.' And despite leaving Wembley victorious Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino also admitted he is not convinced by VAR.

'I don't like the VAR. Today we get the benefit of it but after watching the World Cup and another league like La Liga I see that nobody is happy from day one that they started to use it,' said Pochettino.

'To get the benefit is nice but I am unhappy to win the game like this. I prefer the technology but in a different way. Being clear.

'I am pro technology because you cannot stop evolution but we are waiting so long, it is not clear what are the rules.

'We all have to agree, the players, the coaching staff, I watch every week La Liga and nobody is happy, the big clubs and the small clubs.

'If you are playing to win the title or to stay up nobody is happy.

'That is a good example for us. We have six months to improve the system and there is a lot of work to do.'

item.description: The 31-year-old had six months left on contract and Mauricio Pochettino is willing to sell the Belgium international as he has plenty of cover in midfield and talks are progressing.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham have accepted an Â£11m offer from Beijing Guoan for Mousa Dembele, as revealed by Sportsmail.

The 31-year-old had six months left on contract and Mauricio Pochettino is willing to sell the Belgium international as he has plenty of cover in midfield and talks are progressing.

Dembele is fit again after his ankle ligament injury and has been training but wasn't in the squad to face Chelsea in the League Cup semi-final first leg on Tuesday night.


He's been struggling with the rigours of a Premier League season at 31 and is open to a move with the Chinese offering a lucrative contract.

Tottenham are willing to sell owing to the emergence of Oliver Skipp and the resurgence of Moussa Sissoko.

Eric Dier is returning to fitness as is Victor Wanyama who looks likely to stay.

Pochettino confirmed on Monday: 'I've heard nothing yet. I know like you there are a lot of rumours.

'If something arrives we are going to listen and then it's what we want to do or the player wants to do, it's about to negotiate, talk, like always it happens in that business.'

item.title: Keep the flag down! Assistant referees must follow FIFA protocol and let play continue if VAR is to work in England
item.description: MARK CLATTENBURG: I know VAR eventually got the decision right to award Tottenham a penalty against Chelsea and overturn the initial offside, but the officials are going about it the wrong way.
item.content:encoded:
I know VAR eventually got the decision right to award Tottenham a penalty and overturn the initial offside, but the officials are going about it the wrong way.

Assistant referees are flagging for marginal offside decisions. Why are England not following the way FIFA implemented VAR in the World Cup? What FIFA recommend is to keep the flag down. If a goal is scored, then the offside decision will be checked by VAR.

Had Michael Oliver blown his whistle before Harry Kane was brought down, or Kane or the keeper had stopped when they saw the flag, then the wrong decision would have stood.

That is why it is important to keep the flag down on marginal offside calls and allow the play to continue.

item.title: 'I look at the table and it is just not good enough': Everton chief Farhad Moshiri believes life under Marco Silva has not gone to plan so far but admits he has faith in 'big bet' appointment
item.description: Everton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri believes the club's season has not been good enough, but remains confident the 'big bet' they took on manager Marco Silva will pay off.
item.content:encoded:
Everton's majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri believes the club's season has not been good enough, but remains confident the 'big bet' they took on manager Marco Silva will pay off.

The Toffees sit 11th in the table, having won just one of their last eight Premier League matches. They have 27 points, the same tally they had at the same stage a year ago, and are 17 points off fourth.

It is not where Moshiri would have expected them to be, having upped his investment in the club to Â£250million and dispensed with Sam Allardyce and director of football Steve Walsh at the end of last season at considerable expense to bring in replacements Silva and Marcel Brands.


'We are very serious about what we want to do,' Moshiri told the club's AGM.

'I look at the table and it is just not good enough, I think we know that. We need to go up the table.

'We've had bad luck, poor judgement, but I feel the business we did in the summer shows we are in the right direction, but it has been difficult.

'We did our homework and we put a big bet on Marco and we stick with him.

'He has our total support and we have a professional Marcel Brands who monitors the progress.

'Consistency has been an issue, but we have had terrific performances and the challenge in the second half is to have more of those performances.

'The football management team are totally focused on it. We know what we are and I'm comfortable.'

Moshiri has also pledged to fill the considerable funding gap likely to be left when the finances for the proposed new Â£500million stadium at Bramley-Moore Dock are finalised.

Planning permission is set to be submitted in the second half of this year, with the first 'spade in the ground' anticipated in early 2020.

After a number of false dawns over previous projects Moshiri is adamant the stadium will be built.

'It has nothing to do with my vision, it is a necessity. That must be understood - we don't have a choice, we don't have a Plan B or a Plan C,' he added.

'Very much like Arsenal and Tottenham that had to build a stadium - they were not given stadiums like West Ham or Manchester City.

'We have a lot of experience so I think we will complete this stadium, be sure that will happen. And I will throw as much money as needed.

'Private markets will provide Â£350m, naming rights will give us some more and we maybe have an equity gap of Â£100m.

'I think this club, under the management of Marcel and leadership of Denise (Barrett-Baxendale, the club's chief executive) is sufficiently robust to see the project through. It is no luxury, we have to get it done.

'If we want to have a big club we need a modern stadium and we will get it.'

item.title: The Ian Wooldridge Award: Sportsmail reporters give their picks for annual prize... but decision is up to you
item.description: Established in honour of Sportsmail legend Ian Wooldridge, who died in 2007, this annual award is voted for by you. Here, our writers offer some suggestions. Roger Federer won last year.
item.content:encoded:
Established in honour of Sportsmail legend Ian Wooldridge, who died in 2007, this annual award is voted for by you.

It celebrates the sporting genius and Corinthian spirit so beloved of â€˜Woolersâ€™.

Last year the winner was Roger Federer, who added a 20th Grand Slam title to his record-breaking haul.

Now we invite you to nominate a sportsperson from this year. Email your vote to wooldridgeaward@dailymail.co.uk

Here, our writers offer some suggestions...


PAUL NEWMAN

Nominee: Alastair Cook

There can only be one winner this year. How Ian would have loved to have been at The Oval last summer to see Alastair Cook mark his final Test with a hundred in a winning cause.

Iâ€™m sure Woolers would have been on his feet applauding like the rest of us. This was the perfect goodbye for an outstanding cricketer and, most pertinently, an outstanding individual who represented all the qualities our great columnist so held dear.

Ian would have admired the dignity Cook always demonstrated off the pitch and the sheer will to win and character he showed on it to make the very best of his ability.

IAN HERBERT

Nominee: Lizzy Yarnold

Her competitive record is testament to the spirit Ian so cherished, even before the obstacles she overcame are put into the equation.

A village near the A20 in Kent is not the most auspicious place to be brought up for an individual aspiring to win medals in the skeleton, though Yarnold never seemed to see difficulties as impediments.

Defending her Sochi Winter Olympics gold in South Korea last February meant overcoming chronic back pain, a severe chest infection and the vestibular disorder which made her dizzy and disorientated after her first run.

She prevailed, becoming Britainâ€™s most successful Winter Olympian.

JEFF POWELL

Nominee: Tyson Fury

NOBODY loved a maverick more than Woolers and Tyson Fury is the godfather of all sporting non-conformists.

While he may have been uneasy about the extreme beliefs Fury expresses, Woolers would have been the first to salute his journey along the hard road to redemption.

My much-missed colleague also relished a comeback and would have applauded Tysonâ€™s return to the ring at the forefront of the heavyweight division with that last-round resurrection in his epic draw with Deontay Wilder.

MIKE DICKSON

Nominee: Tommy Fleetwood

I suspect this twinkle-eyed Lancastrian would have won Ianâ€™s admiration. His odd couple partnership-friendship at the Ryder Cup with Francesco Molinari was the pivot around which Europe dismantled the Americans.

It was not just the precision of Fleetwoodâ€™s play, but the joy with which this grounded and likeable individual embraced the pressure on his debut.

Him being carried aloft by fans, his straggly hair bouncing around, will become one of the Ryder Cupâ€™s most enduring images.

DEREK LAWRENSON

Nominee: Georgia Hall

Woolers was in his element when covering the Open, and how he would have enjoyed the story of the golf-mad plastererâ€™s girl who won the womenâ€™s equivalent at Royal Lytham.

Born during Sir Nick Faldoâ€™s third Masters triumph at Augusta in 1996, and duly named in honour of his achievement, she achieved something to place alongside his feats with a stunning success, calmly holding off the worldâ€™s best in front of an adoring crowd.

MATT LAWTON

Nominee: Billy Monger

Geraint Thomas might have won the BBCâ€™s Sports Personality of the Year award after his Tour de France glory, but in Birmingham that night one young motor racing driver stood alone for his extraordinary courage.

Billy Monger was only 17 when he was involved in an horrific crash in an F4 British Championship race at Donington in 2017. He needed to have both legs amputated.

But Billy hasnâ€™t just learned to walk again with the aid of prosthetic legs. He is back behind the wheel of a racing car modified to his requirements after gaining the approval of the FIA and finished third in a British Formula 3 race at Oulton Park on his return.

One imagines Ian would consider him more than worthy of the award named in his honour.

JONATHAN McEVOY

Nominee: Alastair Cook

Woolers would surely have appreciated the unlikely â€˜rebelâ€™ in Alastair Cook, the one blithely out of step with the Instagram-style whirl of modern sport. Defying every known fad, he was a devotee of deer-stalking rather than tattoo parlours.

It was for his decency and his shunning of personal glory as much as his record 12,472 Test runs that The Oval crowd stood in long and sincere tribute when he signed off England duty with a century.

The people recognised that he had delivered every last ounce of his talent through patience, dedication and concentration.

RIATH AL-SAMARRAI

Nominee: Dina Asher-Smith

Immense quality and not a trace of ego. One story that goes some way to summing up the latter centres on trips to her local coffee shop.

She went in there for six months and was simply known by her name, her order and her tendency to get into chats with the staff. It was only when she went to Berlin in August and won three European sprint titles that the shopâ€™s manager had any idea of her other life because Asher-Smith had never brought it up.

Now she is the arguably the leading British female in any sport and you sense she is only getting started.

item.title: 'Eden Hazard is too good for this Chelsea team': Jermaine Jenas believes Belgium star was best player on the pitch despite Tottenham win
item.description: Tottenham Hotspur defeated Chelsea 1-0 at Wembley in the first leg of the Carabao Cup semi-final on Tuesday night, thanks to a penalty from Harry Kane.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham Hotspur defeated Chelsea 1-0 at Wembley in the first leg of the Carabao Cup semi-final on Tuesday night.

After a VAR decision, Spurs were awarded a penalty, which Harry Kane converted with his usual calmness.

However it was Chelsea who had the lion's share of possession, with Eden Hazard pulling the strings, as he has become accustomed to doing in this team.


Former Tottenham player Jermaine Jenas had no doubts that Hazard was the best player on the pitch, but his words he used may worry some Chelsea fans.

Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Live after the match, Jenas said: 'How good has Hazard been tonight? Demanding the ball, going by players.

'I never thought I would say it, but he's too good for this Chelsea team.'

It was a disappointing loss for Chelsea, who had 58% of possession and 17 shots on goal. However, with only five of those being on target, questions were raised once again about their lack of a world class striker.

Hazard and Callum Hudson-Odoi were the highlights for Chelsea, but with Bayern Munich after the youngster, and with the Belgian not exactly keeping his desire to play for Real Madrid a secret, Chelsea supporters are starting to have some concerns.

Tottenham were aware of Chelsea's star man too. Eden Hazard won seven of Chelsea's 10 free kicks on the night, the highest number of times he's been fouled in a single game so far this season.

item.content:encoded:
England's Jos Buttler and Joe Root bowed out of the Big Bash in defeat on Tuesday.

Buttler was lbw for five while Root was yet to get off the mark when rain cut short Sydney Thunderâ€™s reply to Brisbane Heat, who won by 15 runs on Duckworth Lewis method.

The pair now depart for England duty in the West Indies.

Buttler leaves as top-scorer for his seven games in the competition, scoring 273 runs at a strike rate of 135 and an average of 39.

Root by contrast failed to make an impression, scoring only 99 runs in seven innings with a high score of just 26.


England begin their tour of the Caribbean against a West Indies Board XI next Tuesday before the first of a three-match Test series starts on January 23.

Their World Cup preparations will then kick in with a five-match ODI series to finish their winter exploits.

item.title: Peter Beardsley has now been suspended for ONE YEAR on full pay over racism and bullying claims... what ARE Newcastle United playing at?
item.description: Beardsley has now been suspended on full pay for exactly one year amid allegations of racism and bullying against. The drawn-out process has left fans questioning the competency of the club.
item.content:encoded:
Peter Beardsley has now been suspended on full pay for exactly one year by Newcastle United amid allegations of racism and bullying against the coach.

The club are refusing to comment on the progress of their internal investigation â€” headed by managing director Lee Charnley â€” even though the majority of the players who brought the claims have since been released and manager Rafa Benitez called for the matter to be 'sorted out' in August.

The drawn-out process has left supporters questioning the competency of the club.


Michael Martin, founder of Newcastle fanzine True Faith, told Sportsmail: 'The club have dithered and this does not reflect well on them. But this, I'm afraid, is to be expected where Newcastle United are concerned.

'Surely it cannot take a full year to gather witness statements, let Peter Beardsley respond to the allegations and then reach an outcome based on that evidence? A matter of this nature should be a priority.

'How does it look to parents of any young players they hope to attract that a coach has been suspended for a year amid serious allegations and no decision has been made? It is an unsatisfactory situation for supporters and is not fair on anyone involved â€” be that the players, academy staff or Peter Beardsley.'

Sources have told Sportsmail they do not expect Beardsley to return to his role as Under 23s coach and the mood around the academy is said to be transformed with ex-Toon goalkeeper Steve Harper having stepped up to assist new boss Ben Dawson.

Several players made allegations last January, and Sportsmail revealed at the end of last season that an independent appeal found the former England forward did make discriminatory comments, and that his treatment of Yasin Ben El-Mhanni was 'generally unfair'.

Academy players have openly made their feelings about Beardsley (left) known during his period of leave and there was one training-ground sing-along this season which saw lyrics adapted to mention their former coach.

Sportsmail also revealed last year that Newcastle were urged to investigate Beardsley's treatment of academy players as far back as 2016, after the family of England youth international Lewis Gibson contacted the club to raise concerns.

A grievance meeting was then scheduled and attended by the player and his family, as well as Beardsley, Charnley and academy director Joe Joyce.

But Beardsley refused to accept he had done anything wrong and said he would not change his ways. He was allowed to continue in his role and it was to the dismay of many within the academy when Gibson reluctantly left his boyhood club in July 2017 to join Everton, in a deal which may rise to Â£6million.

The Premier League and the FA have told Sportsmail that the investigation remains the concern of the club and Beardsley has even attended FA coaching courses at St George's Park over the past 12 months.

Beardsley denies all of the allegations.

item.title: Tottenham 1-0 Chelsea PLAYER RATINGS: Paulo Gazzaniga solid for Spurs but Harry Kane is the star man in Carabao Cup semi-final first leg
item.description: Tottenham ground out a 1-0 win over London rivals Chelsea in Tuesday's Carabao Cup semi-final first leg at Wembley. Harry Kane won and converted the penalty kick which separated the sides.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham ground out a 1-0 win over London rivals Chelsea in Tuesday's Carabao Cup semi-final first leg at Wembley.

Harry Kane won and converted the penalty kick which separated the sides on a night when Chelsea dominated in terms of possession and shots.

At the other end Tottenham goalkeeper Paulo Gazzaniga impressed on his eighth appearance of the season. Spurs have still won every match in which the Argentina stopper has featured.

Sportsmail's SAMI MOKBEL was at Wembley to pass judgement on the players involved.


TOTTENHAM (4-2-3-1)

Paulo Gazzaniga 7/10 - Made an excellent save to deny Hudson-Odoi's deflected effort. Safe handling.

Kieran Trippier 6.5/10 - Kept on his toes by Willian and Alonso but still offered options in attack.

Davinson Sanchez 6.5/10 - Stood firm in defence for the Blues. Still needs someone more experienced alongside, though. Booked.

Toby Alderweireld 7/10 - Organised his back-four with the sort of expertise you'd expect. Cool on a heated night.

Danny Rose 6/10 - Needed eyes on the back of his head with Hudson-Odoi's movement.

Harry Winks 7/10 - Maturity beyond his years. Sat in front of his back four with the discipline of a seasoned campaigner. Booked.

Moussa Sissoko 6/10 - Full of energy in central midfield but struggled to have the impact he's had of late.

Dele Alli 6.5/10 - Threatened as he picked up promising positions all night. His ball retention was excellent.

Christian Eriksen 6.5/10 - So easy on the eye. Spurs must sort his contract out ASAP.

Son Heung-min 6/10 - His pace caused Chelsea problems and had a strong penalty appeal rejected.

Harry Kane 7.5/10 - Changed the game with his run to win the penalty and eventually converting it.

Manager: Mauricio Pochettino 6.5/10 - His side weren't at their best, but the advantage is so valuable. He'd have taken that before kick-off.

CHELSEA (4-3-3)

Kepa 6/10 - Gave away the decisive penalty but didn't let that mistake affect his performance.

Cesar Azpilicueta 6/10 - Saw plenty of the ball but couldn't utilise possession in an attacking sense.

Antonio Rudiger 7/10 - A no nonsense display from the German. Kept his defence together when they were rocking.

Andreas Christensen 6.5/10 - A beautiful turn deep inside his own half illustrated his ability. Deserves more chances.

Marcos Alonso 6/10 - Booed every time he got the ball. But he took it all in his stride. A willing runner on the left.

N'Golo Kante 7/10 - As dynamic as ever and troubled Gazzaniga from distance on more than one occasion.

Jorginho 6/10 - Subdued early on but grew into the game. Not the same influence as earlier in the season.

Ross Barkley 6.5/10 - On the peripheries during the first half, but saw more of the ball as Chelsea improved.

Callum Hudson-Odoi 7/10 - Arguably the biggest night of his fledgling career. Enhanced his already burgeoning reputation.

Eden Hazard 7/10 - Was at his best when he dropped deeper in the second half. Still doesn't look comfortable centrally.

Willian 6/10 - Showed flashes of what he's capable of but not enough. Hooked in the second half.

Manager: Maurizio Sarri 6/10 - His side were much improved in the second half and have a real shot a Wembley.

Referee: Michael Oliver 7/10 - Used VAR very well at Wembley. The key decision of the night.

item.title: Callum Hudson-Odoi proves his worth and VAR can't come fast enough to the Premier League
item.description: CHRIS SUTTON: Tottenham Hotspur earned a narrow 1-0 win in the first leg of the Carabao Cup semi-final against Chelsea at Wembley, thanks to a penalty from Harry Kane.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham Hotspur earned a narrow 1-0 win in the first leg of the Carabao Cup semi-final against Chelsea at Wembley.

Even though Chelsea had the lion's share of possession, it was Harry Kane's penalty, which came about after a lengthy VAR decision, which decided the game.

Here, Sportsmail's Chris Sutton takes you through what happened with his big match analysis.


Hudson-Odoi rewards Sarri's show of faith

For a great team like Bayern Munich to be willing to pay Â£35million for Callum Hudson-Odoi tells us what a talent he is.

His performance against Tottenham, albeit in defeat, told us that, too.

What impresses me most is that he doesnâ€™t show any fear.

He has that swagger about him, despite being only 18 years old. He knows when to release the ball, too.

He is young and can improve but he is an excellent prospect. He looked Chelseaâ€™s biggest threat.

The issue for Maurizio Sarri is that a manager is there to win games and he has players at his disposal such as Pedro and Willian. But it is about time Chelsea gave their best youngsters a chance and it was a big show of faith by Sarri to start Hudson-Odoi at Wembley.

Chelsea and Tottenham's best chance for silverware

You could see from the starting line-ups that both managers know this is their best chance of winning a trophy this season.

Both had to go with strong sides.

And it paid off for Tottenham.

Neither manager has won a major trophy in his career.

It is the age-old problem for Spurs and Mauricio Pochettino. No matter how good they are, they need to win one. And now what a chance they have, going into the second leg in front.

It is important for Sarri, following Antonio Conte who had great success, to land some silverware as soon as possible. That would take the pressure off. He has a job to do now.

I'm convinced! VAR can't come to the Premier League fast enough

I did not like VAR at first, but I am a convert. The penalty incident last night is exactly what VAR is for. It may have taken well over a minute-and-a-half to make the decision, but so what?

To be honest, I quite liked the theatre of the decision-making.

Ultimately, the officials came to the correct decision and that is everything.

Had VAR not been available and Tottenham not been given a penalty, the home side would have been denied their winning goal. That would have felt like an injustice.

There are always going to be teething problems. Would we like it quicker? Yes. But this decision wasnâ€™t the easiest and the outcome was right.

That is what VAR is for. It cannot come into the Premier League quickly enough.

Nerves of steel from 12 yards

If I had a penalty to save my life, there is no one else in the world I would want to take it for me than Harry Kane.

I never thought he was going to miss it. What makes him the best from 12 yards is he has a supreme clear head as well as his sublime execution.

His mental strength reminds me of Alan Shearer. It is no surprise that he has scored his last 15 penalties for club and country.

item.title: Jurgen Klopp faces anxious wait on Dejan Lovren scan results as Liverpool boss faces defensive crisis ahead of Premier League trip to Brighton
item.description: It is expected Dejan Lovren will miss Saturday's trip to Brighton for the Premier League leaders, forcing Jurgen Klopp to field Fabinho as a makeshift partner for Virgil van Dijk.
item.content:encoded:
Jurgen Klopp is facing concern over his defence with Virgil Van Dijk currently Liverpool's only fit senior centre back.

Dejan Lovren was forced off inside six minutes of the FA Cup loss to Wolves and underwent a scan on his left thigh on Tuesday.

The results, due on Wednesday, will determine the scale of Klopp's dilemma with Joe Gomez and Joel Matip already sidelined.


It is expected Lovren will miss Saturday's trip to Brighton at least, forcing Klopp to field Fabinho as a makeshift partner for Van Dijk. Klopp tried his Brazilian midfielder in central defence at Molineux in anticipation of any further issues to his backline.

If the pain Lovren experienced was down to a significant hamstring injury he could be out for six weeks, to join Gomez and Matip in the treatment room. Gomez has been out since suffering a break in his lower left leg during Liverpool's 3-1 win at Burnley on December 5, while Matip required surgery after fracturing his collarbone in the Champions League clash with Napoli at Anfield on December 11.

It is believed Matip could be fit for the visit of Crystal Palace on January 19, but Gomez may not return until February depending on how rehabilitation goes.

In the meantime Klopp is left with a problem at the heart of a defence which has been imperious this season. Van Dijk's presence is reassuring for the Premier League leaders, who have conceded just 10 goals all campaign, but thrusting Fabinho into a match against a striker as physical as Glenn Murray is far from ideal.

Ki-Jana Hoever, the 16-year-old centre back who became Liverpool's youngest player in FA Cup history, impressed after replacing Lovren but is seen as too green to put into the midst of a title challenge.

Liverpool are looking to get back to winning ways after losing at Manchester City and suffering consecutive defeats for the first time this season.

James Milner accepted his mistake cost Liverpool their place in the FA Cup but plans to bounce back immediately at Brighton.

The veteran midfielder erred for the Wolves opener. 'It's one of those, I should do better,' he said.

But Milner insisted all teams will have a 'blip' and called on his team-mates to respond in the right manner to avoid concern spreading. 'Back to back defeats isn't really good enough for us but you have blips in a season,' said Milner.

'They are expected but it's how you respond. You've seen the character in the squad over the last few years and the players we have to know we will bounce back. We have to do that at the weekend.'

item.title: 'I take cups seriously': As Manchester City prepare for Burton in the Carabao Cup semi-final, is Pep Guardiola having a pop at Jurgen Klopp?
item.description: Pep Guardiola has not had much time to prepare for Burton. Tuesday afternoon was only the second occasion he had sat down with chief analyst Carles Planchart.
item.content:encoded:
Pep Guardiola has not had much time to prepare for Burton. Tuesday afternoon was only the second occasion he had sat down with chief analyst Carles Planchart to work out how Nigel Clough will approach this Carabao Cup semi-final.

Yet there is resonance to Guardiolaâ€™s words when he speaks about respecting Manchester Cityâ€™s League One visitors.

This might be a relatively low-key tie, particularly compared to Tottenhamâ€™s two-legged affair with Chelsea, but these are the nights Guardiola cherishes.


Reaching Wembley again would be another landmark achievement in his quest to make City a â€˜greatâ€™ club. And as such, he is refusing to prioritise any competition because silverware â€” in whichever form it arrives â€” rules for a man obsessed by trophies.

â€˜I prefer it to be in the four competitions as far as possible,â€™ Guardiola (right) said. â€˜When Wigan put us out of the FA Cup last season, I was sad. I take the cups seriously.â€™

City want to generate winning momentum and plan to do that with a sprinkling of changes. Guardiola made nine for the 7-0 win over Rotherham on Sunday and is tinkering again.

Kevin De Bruyne will continue his managed return to full fitness, hopeful of playing longer than the 67 minutes he was given in the FA Cup.

Other stellar names will feature. They will supplement a number of youngsters, with Aro Muric in goal, while 17-year-old Eric Garcia is also in the mix. Phil Foden is confident of a second start in four days.

Guardiola believes City can handle all four competitions providing he rotates his side carefully. Jurgen Klopp attempted a similar trick on Monday night but suffered defeat at Wolves, which leaves Liverpool with a lighter load. The Premier League champions could end up playing eight more domestic matches than Liverpool should they reach the Carabao Cup and FA Cup finals.

â€˜Iâ€™m not involved in what my opponents do,â€™ Guardiola said.

â€˜The reality for Jurgen is he knows exactly what happened.

â€˜Iâ€™m not the right person to judge what the others do because I donâ€™t like it when others judge our decisions.

â€˜You cannot survive in any league in the world fighting for the title with just 12 or 13 players. Itâ€™s impossible. You need a bigger squad and every player has to be a top player.

â€˜Since I arrived weâ€™ve played Manchester United with a lot of young players (in the 2016 League Cup). It was the same the second season, the same the third season, thatâ€™s what happened.

â€˜Against Rotherham we played with nine players who didnâ€™t play against Liverpool and the nine were a good selection.â€™

Guardiola scoffed at suggestions that City tampered with the Etihad Stadium pitch before last weekâ€™s manic 2-1 victory over their title rivals.

It was claimed they allowed the grass to grow much longer than the 23 millimetres the manager usually demands.

â€˜If Liverpool want to play quick, we want to play quicker, so we never manipulated that,â€™ he added. â€˜I never do something to trick. Normally when this kind of thing happens, always at the endâ€¦ karma or something like that punishes you.

â€˜I trust the greenkeepers. Iâ€™ve never made a phone call to one to say do this kind of thing to damage our opponents.â€™

City left back Benjamin Mendy is ready to return from a knee injury before the end of the month, while City are in discussions over a new contract with centre half Vincent Kompany.

Guardiola and Kompany both want to extend the captainâ€™s 11-year stay beyond the summer. â€˜We are considering it â€” I would like it,â€™ Guardiola said. â€˜We saw in the last games the huge quality and personality he has to play. The only problem is his injury problems.

â€˜One-against-one, absolutely weâ€™re better when Vincent plays. Every central defender has his own quality but thereâ€™s no doubt Vincent has something special.

â€˜Heâ€™s one of the best central defenders Iâ€™ve ever seen.â€™

item.title: FA Cup exit at Wolves was Liverpool's best defeat of the season... Jurgen Klopp can finally do some work on the training ground and players can rest as they battle for Premier League title
item.description: DOMINIC KING: Losing to Wolves should not be viewed as the calamity that some have tried to make out. Klopp, certainly, wonâ€™t lose any sleep over the 2-1 FA Cup defeat with the bigger picture in mind.
item.content:encoded:
When the final whistle sounds at Anfield after Crystal Palaceâ€™s visit on January 19, Jurgen Klopp will be in a position of rare luxury.

From 4.50pm on Saturday week, Klopp will be able to give his players a few days off to recharge tired minds and aching limbs and â€” above all â€” know he has a window in which he can do some proper work on the training ground.

It has been a bugbear for Liverpoolâ€™s manager that work at Melwood on shape and tactics has been limited recently. A schedule of 12 matches in 44 days since November 24 has given Klopp no time to go in depth on the areas that need improvement but he can now see a window where that changes.


Losing to Wolves should not be viewed as the calamity that some have tried to make out.

Klopp, certainly, wonâ€™t lose any sleep over the 2-1 FA Cup defeat at Molineux with the bigger picture in mind. He will have received clarity on some key factors, too.

Klopp gave an opportunity to some players to show they should be in his plans for the remainder of the campaign, but senior figures such as Simon Mignolet, Alberto Moreno and Daniel Sturridge failed to grasp the moment. Naby Keita, meanwhile, continues to struggle with the English game.

Shout at the manager for putting nine new faces in, but arenâ€™t they the ones who are able to shape the destiny of a game? Liverpool could have got a draw â€” think of Xherdan Shaqiriâ€™s glorious free-kick â€” but, ultimately, they were beaten away from home by a very good team. No drama. Move on.

Had Liverpool been off the pace in the Premier League â€” with finishing in the top four their best hope â€” out of Europe and the Carabao Cup, Klopp would not have been able to defend his decision to make so many changes in Wolverhampton and every inch of criticism that followed would have been just.

Take a glance at the Premier League table, though, and have a look at what Liverpool are fighting for. Every fan has wanted this prize for 29 years and the team have never been in a better position to deliver it.

People can rant and rave about Klopp treating the FA Cup with disrespect, but the fact is Wolves inflicted Liverpoolâ€™s best defeat of the season by some considerable distance.

Indeed, it looks like they have been done a favour.

For when Liverpool return to action against Leicester City on January 30 â€” and they will have 10 days to get ready for that contest â€” title rivals Manchester City will have played four extra fixtures, with trips to Huddersfield and Newcastle in the Premier League, plus a Carabao Cup tie in Burton and a home FA Cup tie with Burnley.

Of course, it is up to Liverpool to utilise this break, but in a race that is set to be determined by the smallest of margins, every advantage must be grasped.

Going out of the FA Cup is certainly one.

item.title: Tottenham ready to open new stadium in March for the visit of Crystal Palace - as they confirm latest Wembley games
item.description: The long-awaited switch to the new White Hart Lane is not imminent; the club are still conducting final checks and waiting for the appropriate safety certificates.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham will stay at Wembley until at least the end of February as their wait to move into their new stadium goes on.

Spurs' Premier League home games with Watford, Newcastle and Leicester will all be at the national stadium as the finishing touches are put on their 62,000-seater home.

The Champions League last-16 home leg with Borussia Dortmund on February 13 will also be at Wembley, and Sportsmail understands that Spurs are working towards a potential first fixture in March.

Tottenham host bitter rivals Arsenal on March 2 before Crystal Palace travel to face Mauricio Pochettino's men 14 days later.

Given the potential for trouble against Arsenal, and the possibility of losing the first game at their new home to their arch-rivals, there is thought to be a reluctance to open the doors to the state-of-the-art new ground against the Gunners.

That leaves the game against Palace on March 16 as the emerging favourite.


Chairman Daniel Levy has apologised to fans and hopes to provide a further update in the next few weeks.

Levy said on the club's official website on Wednesday: 'I should like to apologise to our fans and thank you for your continued patience.

'The response from those who attended the familiarisation event was great to hear and reinforced our commitment to deliver an exceptional matchday experience for everyone.

'We shall now seek clarity in respect of building test schedules and test event dates and provide further information on these in the next two to three weeks.'

Spurs' final home fixture in February is against Borussia Dortmund in the Champions League on February 13. It seems highly unlikely the new Â£1billion stadium will be ready for that clash.

Spurs have consecutive Premier League home fixtures again Brighton and Huddersfield in April but they hope to have made the move by then.

Tottenham had hoped to have moved in last September but a series of teething problems have forced the club to delay the opening.

item.title: Forget about Australian Open glory... victory for Andy Murray is playing without pain, insists John McEnroe
item.description: EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW BY LAURA LAMBERT: Ahead of the Australian Open, Sportsmail caught up with John McEnroe to talk through British hopes and his favourites for the titles.
item.content:encoded:
Ahead of the Australian Open, which starts on Monday, Sportsmail caught up with John McEnroe to talk through British hopes and his favourites for the titles.

The feisty 59-year-old hopes 2019 is not the year British tennis waves goodbye to Andy Murray, but believes a victory for the Scot at this stage of his career is simply playing without pain.

McEnroe says there are questions surrounding Rafael Nadal and Stan Wawrinka â€” previous Australian Open champions â€” and hopes Kyle Edmund can cope with dropping down the rankings after his stunning run to the semi-finals last year.

As for British No 1 Jo Konta, McEnroe wants to see her develop a Plan B at the first Grand Slam of the season.


Mac on Andy Murray

If he is not 100 per cent, it is limited what he can do. I had a hip problem when I was 26 and I didnâ€™t have surgery like he did so maybe his was even more serious. I felt it affected me for the rest of my career and to this day, in a way. If he is having pain, that is obviously terrible. It was always going to be a tricky injury to get back from, because he relies on his movement.

In Australia, I would imagine he is just trying to get through without being in a lot of pain, so that would be sort of a victory. When you are playing best-of-five-sets, it is quite a bit different to best-of-three and that is a tall order. So, if he is feeling pain and not feeling right, it is hard to imagine he can go too long.

I had about seven years not playing at the level I thought I could. Andy has missed the better part of a year and a half. I assume it is extremely frustrating for him, but I would be surprised if he would not give it at least another year or two to make sure he exhausts every opportunity. Who wants to walk away not on their own terms? Nobody.

Mac on Kyle Edmund

He broke through and had his best tournament in Melbourne last year, and I felt like he had an opportunity to break into the top 10. I just think the pressure has been building for him because he has a lot of ranking points to defend now.

When that happens, the things that bother you a little bit start to bother you more, and it just gets in your head. Injuries have a way of happening when you least want them to. It would be too bad if his knee injury is serious, because he was making real progress for most of last year.

Itâ€™s going to be interesting to see how he handles it in Melbourne, especially if he loses early and his ranking drops. He is going to be feeling a lot of pressure. Getting to the semi-finals of a major, that is a lot of his overall points, so that would definitely hurt his ranking quite a bit.

Mac on Jo Konta

She reached a certain level, she was a semi-finalist at Wimbledon in 2017, and the pressure to live up to that is difficult. The player forgets at times that they have to keep getting better just to stay at that same level. Iâ€™m not saying she didnâ€™t try to do that, I just think it is difficult to do and then you are more of a target with other players and a better opponent because you are ranked higher.

That adds up and it is difficult to maintain. I donâ€™t know her, but Iâ€™m assuming she put a lot of pressure on herself to try to improve her ranking and her best results, and in a way the pressure got to her.

She needs to add more to her game. She is very aggressive and is much more comfortable being offensive and controlling points. Against some of the top players you are not able to do that consistently and you need to have a Plan B, a back-up. You need to be able to fall back on some defence. The best players are those who are able to do that successfully. There are too many players who do not learn that.

Mac on young Guns

One of these kids is going to break through this year and win a major. Whether it is Karen Khachanov or Stefanos Tsitsipas or Alex Zverev, I donâ€™t know right now, itâ€™s hard to pick. I believe there will be a changing of the guard.

Mac on whoâ€™ll win in Melbourne

Australia is the most unpredictable Grand Slam because you donâ€™t know the health of people. Nadal is a question mark, obviously Murray and Wawrinka, whoâ€™ve missed a lot of time, are question marks. Some of it depends on the draw.

Novak Djokovic has had great success in Australia and has won it six times, so it is hard at this stage â€” especially the way he finished last year â€” not to say that it looks like itâ€™s him. Roger Federer has positioned himself to make a good run, too.

The womenâ€™s side is more unpredictable. It is hard for me not to pick Serena, even though you donâ€™t know what has happened since the US Open. She looks in good shape and itâ€™s too unpredictable with the other players, as there are 10 or 15 women who could win it.

item.title: Danny Cipriani poised for Munster comeback and a new Gloucester deal
item.description: Danny Cipriani could be thrown straight back into action against Munster in the Heineken Champions Cup after recovering from a chest injury suffered in the defeat by Exeter a month ago.
item.content:encoded:
Danny Cipriani could be thrown straight back into action against Munster in the Heineken Champions Cup after recovering from a chest injury.

And in a major boost to Gloucester the fly-half, 31, is ready to commit to a new deal.

Cipriani last featured in the European defeat by Exeter a month ago, when he hurt his pectoral muscle.

Coach Johan Ackermann is giving him every chance to make the crunch clash against the Irish province at Kingsholm on Friday.

'If you ask Danny, he is ready to go. That's a good sign for us,' Ackermann told Sportsmail.

'Danny has a fitness test on Thursday, hopefully he comes through. Yesterday was a big marker because we had a semi-contact training. He did his own contact yesterday, too.


'If the medical staff clear him then he'll be up for selection. I will give him as much time as possible, as it has been a short turnaround from Leicester on Saturday, but will take guidance from the medical team.

'I like it if players are as strong as they were before the injury.'

Cipriani took a pay cut â€” downgrading early demands of a Â£400,000 salary at Wasps â€” when he moved to Gloucester last summer.

His deal runs until the summer of 2020, but he is keen to stay longer.

The fly-half and the club are already negotiating an extension to his deal and Ackermann said it does not depend on his England selection.

Cipriani would surely command a huge hike in wages if he sacrificed his national team dream and moved to France or Japan, but his coach said that is not part of the discussions.

'Danny is open-minded on England,' said the South African. 'He is not putting his house on that. He knows where he stands with Eddie Jones and what he needs to do.

'This is purely a decision that he wants to stay in the English competition â€” and it is a privilege he wants to stay with Gloucester specifically.

'The World Cup is this year, so he could have signed, stayed until the 2019-20 season and then gone wherever.

'The fact that he wants to extend beyond that puts the club's ambitions before England. He wants to stay regardless of what happens with England.

'It is a big compliment if a player of his quality wants to stay with us so we can bring his career on. Hopefully it can be done.'

item.title: Tottenham 1-0 Chelsea: Harry Kane's VAR-assisted penalty gives Spurs first-leg advantage in Carabao Cup semi-final
item.description: MATT BARLOW AT WEMBLEY: Tottenham might be cooling on the Wembley experience but the prospect of a return in a cup final ought to be enough to rekindle the glow.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham might be cooling on the whole Wembley experience but the prospect of a return in a cup final ought to be enough to rekindle the glow.

There is still work to do at Stamford Bridge if Mauricio Pochettino is to lead his team out in the Carabao Cup final on February 24.

Chelsea responded once behind and it is well within their powers of recovery to turn it around when these London rivals meet again in a fortnight, in a competition where away goals do not count.

MATCH FACTS, PLAYER RATINGS AND MATCH ZONE

Tottenham (4-1-3-1): Gazzaniga 7, Trippier 6.5, Alderweireld 7, Sanchez 6.5, Rose 6, Winks 7 (Skipp 89min), Sissoko 6, Eriksen 6.5 (Llorente 90+1), Alli 6.5, Kane 7.5, Son 6 (Lamela 79)

Subs not used: Walker-Peters, Davies, Lloris, Foyth

Goalscorers: Kane pen 27

Booked: Winks, Sanchez, Lamela

Manager: Mauricio Pochettino 6.5

Chelsea (4-3-3): Kepa 6, Azpilicueta 6, Rudiger 7, Christensen 6.5, Alonso 6, Kante 7, Jorginho 6, Barkley 6.5 (Kovacic 75, 6), Willian 6 (Pedro 63, 6), Hazard 7, Hudson-Odoi 7 (Giroud 79)

Subs not used: Caballero, Zappacosta, Ampadu, Luiz

Booked: Kepa

Manager: Maurizio Sarri 6

Referee: Michael Oliver 7

Man of the Match: Harry Kane

Ratings by Sami Mokbel

The advantage, however, belongs to Spurs at the half way stage, courtesy of a first-half penalty scored by Harry Kane and awarded with the help of the video assistant referee.

This time there was no malfunction with the new technology as the officials reached the right decision, ruling out offside and confirming the foul inside a couple of minutes.

Kane stepped forward to score in a sixth successive appearance. Very rarely does he malfunction these days.

Pochettino will have little opportunity to dwell on the result as he turns his attention to facing a rejuvenated Manchester United but he will be proud of the way his team dug in to resist Chelsea's fight back in the second half.

At times, it was not pretty. Certainly not the fluent attacking style Tottenham are capable of producing but it was precisely the sort of rugged, winning football their Argentine manager admires and wants to see more often.

He called for naughtiness on the eve of the game. Perhaps it put his players in the right frame of mind. There were scuffles, although nothing quite as unruly as the infamous 'Battle of the Bridge' in 2016.

Chelsea did not buckle either, as they had in the Premier League in November and deserved an equaliser.


Twice Maurizio Sarri's side struck the frame of the goal in the closing stages of the first half and they dominated for long spells in control after the interval.

They had 17 efforts at goal, according to the statistical wizards, with only five on target and found Paulo Gazzaniga still in terrific form, as he has been throughout this competition.

Sarri can be encouraged by aspects of the second half, the way they moved the ball and stretched Spurs and yet will have been hugely frustrated not to find the net, which will intensify his determination to land a new striker in the transfer market.

What would he give for a centre forward like Kane?

There was no sign of Alvaro Morata, scorer of both goals in the win in the FA Cup third round tie on Saturday, and absent with a slight hamstring strain on a day when Sevilla and Valencia explored the idea of signing the Spain striker on loan.

Eden Hazard was back in the centre forward role he doesn't always enjoy and Callum Hudson-Odoi's dazzling second-half display against Nottingham Forest in the FA Cup was enough to earn him another start on a day when Bayern Munich increased their offer to Â£35million.

Hudson-Odoi forced Gazzaniga into an early save in a breathless opening and Kane's overhead kick did not extend Kepa Arrizabalaga.

Pochettino deployed a midfield diamond, a ploy which worked so well in November when Dele Alli smothered Jorginho, but there were no complicated tactics behind the move leading to the only goal.

Toby Alderweireld launched a long, straight and simple ball from central defence into an inside left channel and Kane was first onto it.

With a burst of pace and a toe poke, he nudged it past Arrizabalaga who careered from his goal and with his momentum sent the Spurs striker cartwheeling.

Referee Michael Oliver called for assistance from the VAR. Replays showed the foul was clear but the offside call was tight.

Chelsea players protested as Wembley held its breath until eventually Oliver received the information he needed, pointed to the spot and showed a yellow card to the goalkeeper.

Kane kept his nerve and whipped the penalty kick into the corner of the net.

It was his 160th Tottenham goal and eased him above Cliff Jones and into fourth place in the all-time list of top scorers.

Chelsea hit back. First N'Golo Kante made a darting run and turned a cross from Marcos Alonso against the foot of a post.

Then an attempted cross from Hudson-Odoi clipped Danny Rose and swerved high over Gazzaniga, who adjusted his feet and twisted in the air to produce a fabulous save, turning the ball against the same post with his fingertips.

The rebound spun in front of goal and Alderweireld hoisted it clear as Hudson-Odoi held his head.

Results can hinge on the smallest margins and Spurs reached the sanctuary of half-time with their lead intact and returned with purpose.

Kane tested Arrizabalaga with a fierce drive from distance before Chelsea took control.

Hazard dropped deeper to find more of the ball and influence the game as he had not in the first half and the visitors began to stitch together patterns of possession with a little more menace.

Gazzaniga made diving saves to frustrate Hazard and Kante. Andreas Christensen, at full stretch, was unable to convert at the back post as he arrived alone to reach a corner flicked on by Ross Barkley.

Sarri sent on Pedro on the right to add pace, with Hudson-Odoi switching to the left, and Mateo Kovacic to add fresh legs in search of an equaliser.

There were enthusiastic late appeals for penalties but Tottenham survived. One clean sheet from another game at Wembley, this time with a difference.

item.title: Sunderland 4-0 Newcastle U21: Blacks Cats claim derby spoils in Checkatrade Trophy to stay on course for Wembley final
item.description: CRAIG HOPE AT THE STADIUM OF LIGHT: Jack Ross said this Wear-Tyne derby was â€˜no winâ€™ - but given Sunderland are two games from Wembley it feels like a big victory for their long-suffering fans.
item.content:encoded:
Sunderland boss Jack Ross said this Wear-Tyne derby was â€˜no winâ€™ for his club - but given they are now two games from Wembley it feels like a significant victory for their long-suffering supporters.

There were 16,654 at the Stadium of Light for a Checkatrade Trophy fixture that will enter the hostsâ€™ history books but will be readily discarded as an Under-21 outing by the visitors.

That is why Ross had his reservations - win and theyâ€™ll say you have only beaten the kids, lose and itâ€™s another embarrassing episode for the Netflix cameras.


And the documentary makers were here to record the latest chapter of a story they must surely hope ends in League One promotion and a Wembley final.

So had Ross changed his mind?

â€˜I said it was â€œno winâ€ before the game and I probably got that slightly wrong,â€™ said the Scot. â€˜It wasnâ€™t an ideal fixture against an Under-21 team, it was unusual. But it gets us closer to Wembley and we want to get to that final.

â€˜It has also given me a taste of what a proper derby would be like, and that is still the ambition.â€™

After a nervy first half Sunderlandâ€™s experience told as an own goal by Kelland Watts was followed by Charlie Wykeâ€™s header, Chris Maguireâ€™s long-range strike and Benjamin Kimpiokaâ€™s late effort.

But they did not have it all their own way against what was a weakened Newcastle side.

So concerned is Rafa Benitez about the fitness of his senior midfielders that they could not afford to risk youngster Sean Longstaff here, a player who has made just one substitute appearance in the Premier League.

One of those first-team stars with injury problems is Jonjo Shelvey. He is currently in Barcelona receiving treatment along with defender Paul Dummett and they were trying to access coverage on the clubâ€™s TV station before kick-off.

What they would have seen in the first half was a Newcastle side passing the ball with more composure than Benitezâ€™s men have managed of late.

Boss Ben Dawson said: â€˜In the end I thought 4-0 was harsh. The lads will take a lot from that, the atmosphere was great, our fans never stopped. The players will learn that the higher the level you go the more the finer details matter in games.â€™

The Magpies edged a goalless first half which was better remembered for the insults traded between fans, Newcastleâ€™s â€˜We saw you crying on Netflixâ€™ matched by Sunderlandâ€™s â€˜Six in a rowâ€™ in recognition of their recent derby dominance.

Come the end they were crowing about a seventh win in 10 over their bitter rivals - try telling them this did not matter.

item.title: Metropolitan Police make three arrests for alleged racially aggravated offences during League Cup semi-final between Tottenham and Chelsea
item.description: SAMI MOKBEL AT WEMBLEY: Police confirmed that a 17-year-old male was detained and questioned at a London station for anti-Semitic abuse. A 20 and 23-year-old were also detained.
item.content:encoded:
Police arrested three supporters for racially aggravated offences at Wembley on Tuesday night.

Metropolitan Police confirmed that a 17-year-old male was detained and questioned at a north London police station for anti-Semitic abuse. A 20 and 23-year-old were also detained.

A fourth was arrested on suspicion of possessing drugs.

All eyes were on fans from both clubs given the intense rivalry between them.


Tottenham and Chelsea had appealed to their supporters to behave ahead of the semi-final. Blues fans were specifically asked not to repeat the anti-Semitic chants often sung at games against Spurs.

Five minutes into Tuesday nightâ€™s derby the travelling supporters began their first rendition of a particular chant â€” the one in which they explain exactly how much they â€˜hate Tottenhamâ€™.

The punchline is usually the Y-word. Not on Tuesday night, though, which suggested that many had heeded the appeals of their club hierarchy.

After numerous incidents that have put Chelsea fans under the microscope in recent weeks, all eyes were on their fans here.

To their credit, the majority appeared to be on their best behaviour. You would imagine the half-a-dozen or so security spotters who did not take their eyes off them the entire night had something to do with that. So too the fact Chelsea bought their own stewards to Wembley.

Of course, only those in the closest proximity could be certain.

The home fans, however, were using the Y-word, which could be heard on Sky despite their efforts to mute such chants.

Stepping off the Tube and out of Wembley Park station was like emerging in a scene from The Bill, with a heavier than normal police presence.

Likewise, the usual leisurely walk up Wembley Way was far less relaxed â€” police were everywhere on the route to the stadium. It was a shame that a footballing showpiece should require such measures.

There had been a further spotlight cast on the issue of supporter behaviour earlier in the day, with FA disciplinary chiefs investigating complaints about Nottingham Forest fans who taunted their FA Cup hosts on Saturday at Stamford Bridge with loud chants of â€˜Chelsea rent boysâ€™.

The governing body have written to both clubs for their observations.

Two days earlier, a Chelsea supporter had been fined and banned from football for three years after he admitted using homophobic language during a game at Brighton.

Three Manchester United players took a trip to Salt Bae's Nusr-Et Dubai restaurant on Tuesday as Romelu Lukaku, Anthony Martial and Andreas Pereira made the most of some free-time on their warm-weather training trip.

United are currently in the United Arab Emirates enjoying the sun while preparing for Sunday's Premier League clash with Tottenham at Wembley.

The Red Devils have won five matches in a row under interim manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, so it was no surprise to see Lukaku and Co looking in high spirits as they watched Salt Bae, real name Nusret Gokce, serving them steak.


Lukaku shared footage of the meat master in action. The striker uploaded it to Instagram with the caption: 'Amazing quality and thank you for look (sic) after us'.

Gokce also took to Instagram earlier in the day when he showed off his football skills.

Salt Bae posted a video of himself performing a rainbow flick before volleying a ball against the crossbar of an improvised mini-goal.

United departed for Dubai immediately after Saturday's 2-0 win over Reading. Lukaku scored his third goal in as many matches as Solskjaer's side progressed to round four of the FA Cup.

item.title: Mohamed Salah retains African Player of the Year trophy after stunning 2018 as Liverpool and Egypt striker marks award with awkward dance on stage
item.description: The Egyptian forward helped the Reds to the Champions League final in May and has been a vital part of their assault on the Premier League title so far this season. He retained the prize he won last year.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool's Mohamed Salah has been crowned the 2018 African Player of the Year after a sensational 12 months.

The Egyptian forward helped the Reds to the Champions League final in May and has been a vital part of their assault on the Premier League title so far this season. He retained the prize he won 12 months ago.

And to mark his achievement, the striker was joined on stage by a group of dancers in Dakar, Senegal, as he awkwardly attempted to join in.

Salah enjoyed a record-breaking 2017/18 campaign, scoring 32 goals in the Premier League and 44 across all competitions.


He also scored twice at the World Cup in Egypt's first appearance at the competition in 28 years.

Salah beat fellow nominees, Liverpool team-mate Sadio Mane and Arsenal forward Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang.

He edged the same two players last year in a vote decided by the technical directors and head coaches of 56 CAF member associations.

It completes another award-filled year for the 26-year-old after he also retained the BBC African Footballer of the Year prize and finished sixth in the Ballon dâ€™Or standings.

This magnificently awkward and I love it. Mo Salah dancing like everyone's watching pic.twitter.com/tUEK0yufer

â€” Nooruddean (@BeardedGenius) January 8, 2019

Salah was handed the prize at a ceremony in Dakar on Tuesday night, where he was also included in the Africa Best XI for 2018 alongside Mane and Naby Keita.

Aubameyang was also included with the Premier League providing seven of the 11 players. Manchester City's Riyad Mahrez, Manchester United's Eric Bailly and Tottenham's Serge Aurier were also included.

Medhi Benatia of Juventus, Kalidou Koulibaly of Napoli, Atletico Madrid's Thomas Partey and goalkeeper Denis Onyango of the Mamelodi Sundowns completed the team.

item.title: Tottenham win penalty after referee Michael Oliver consults VAR over whether Harry Kane was offside before Kepa Arrizabalaga brought him down... but fans had no idea what was happening inside Wembley
item.description: Tottenham got off to the perfect start at Wembley in the first leg of their Carabao Cup semi-final against Chelsea. Referee Michael Oliver awarded a penalty after Kane was brought down.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham got off to the perfect start at Wembley in the first leg of their Carabao Cup semi-final against Chelsea.

Harry Kane put Spurs 1-0 up from the penalty spot after he was brought down by Chelsea goalkeeper Kepa Arrizabalaga.

There was confusion, however, when referee Michael Oliver stopped to review footage of the build-up to the foul on Kane.


There was a suggestion that Kane was offside as the ball was played through to him.

The supporters inside Wembley were left clueless and only realised what was happening once the two big screens showed a message saying the referee had gone to VAR.

Once Oliver had consulted the video referee, he decided to award a penalty.

Kane stepped up and slotted his effort from 12 yards down to Arrizabalaga's right and in.

Former Tottenham striker Robbie Keane said: â€˜A lot of people have been complaining about VAR but I think it's great for the game. How long did it take? 93 seconds. It's certainly a penalty. There's no doubt about it.

â€˜For me, he's definitely onside. Very clever from Kane. It was a definite penalty. Red card or yellow card?â€™

VAR is being used in both of the first legs of the Carabao Cup semi-finals.

Manchester City host Burton in the first leg of the second semi-final on Wednesday.
